content:
The Best Hot Dogs in New York City

Photo by @steph.renee.today on Instagram.


New York is world famous for its hot dogs. They're in almost every film, and they're on almost every block. And while you can always stop at a Sabrett street cart (there are hundreds throughout Manhattan), we prefer these gourmet hot dog spots.

DBGB Kitchen & Bar

299 Bowery, Lower East Side

The Dog: DBGB Dog

The Reason: The housemade beef wiener comes with a delicate layering of sautéed onion and star chef Daniel Boulud’s signature “299 relish” of pickled vegetables. Executive chef Ian Vest helms the kitchen, which is a part of Boulud’s growing empire of ever-popular restaurants.


Photo courtesy of Elvert Barnes on Flickr.


Rosamunde Sausage Grill

285 Bedford Ave., Williamsburg, Brooklyn

The Dog: Bourbon bacon-wrapped knockwurst with grilled onions

The Reason: The all-beef sausage is good on its own, but who can resist bourbon bacon? It is our go-to pairing at Rosamunde, a Williamsburg grillhouse with build-your-own hot dog options. Wine on tap (plus 24 draft beers) makes the trek to Brooklyn totally worth it.


Photo courtesy of Molly Müller on Flickr.


Bark

Multiple locations, including 155 Bleecker St., Greenwich Village

The Dog: The Classic Dog

The Reason: Bark has multiple options (sauerkraut dogs, chicken chorizo, cheddar bratwurst, etc.), but we stick to the classic, made with pork belly and pork and beef shoulder, served on a toasted and buttered top-split bun. Owner Joshua Sharkey’s team bastes the sausages with the signature “Bark butter,” a blend of sweet cream butter, sea salt and pork belly fat. Originally a Brooklyn company, Bark opened an outpost in the Village in spring 2015.


Photo courtesy of In NYC by @innycsite on Instagram.


Rusty Knot

425 West St., Meatpacking District

The Dog: Pretzel Dog

The Reason: The extra-long sausage link wrapped in a thick and fluffy layer of pretzel dough goes great with a beer at this popular bar near the High Line. The atmosphere is surprisingly laid-back, considering its Meatpacking location.


Photo courtesy of Ronnie Ruiz, @they_call_me_ronaldo on Instagram.
